block.p: All the participants quoted in the debate gaze upon the murals from street level; they should try an above-ground perspective.

From my apartment on the northeast corner of Houston and Wooster Streets, I enjoy an unobstructed view of no less than 12 such ads. In the privacy of my home, overlooking ground zero of Houston Street, I cannot look south or west out of any window and avoid seeing these murals.

From my apartment on the northeast corner of Houston and Wooster Streets, I enjoy an unobstructed view of no less than 12 such ads. In the privacy of my home, overlooking ground zero of Houston Street, I cannot look south or west out of any window and avoid seeing these murals.

I invite the advertising signage advocates to visit me and experience first-hand the impact. I want to learn if the muralists enjoy the signs' aesthetic value when the signs are literally in their faces.

For three years I have been protesting the muralization of Houston Street to city officials, claiming my right as a resident to live ''free from advertising.'' However, city building and landmark regulations only concern themselves with the view from street level.
Thousands of New Yorkers living in the residential districts that border on nonresidential zones now find themselves surrounded by giant ads.
